Award.AwardTitle: The Role of Radiation in Tropical Cyclone Genesis and Early Intensification
Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
This proposal seeks to transform our knowledge of the role of radiation in tropical cyclogenesis. Evidence suggests that radiation could play a crucial role in the early stages of genesis, particularly with the nighttime cooling and enhanced convection in the early morning hours. However, the complicated pathway to genesis under the influence of radiation and induced circulations is not well understood. Two genesis pathways have been identified in past work by the investigators in this study, and the role of radiation in these pathways will be examined in this research.

Intellectual Merit
This study will add to our understanding of tropical cyclogenesis by elucidating the role of radiation in the core of tropical cyclones and in the surrounding environment. The investigation will also explore other phenomena like the diurnal cycle of deep convection that appear to be connected to radiative forcing. While the vorticity field appears to be full of both positive and negative components near cold pool edges, overall vorticity increases with time. These are cutting-edge questions to explore now that we have the computational horsepower to simulate radiation and microphysics on cloud-resolving grids. Previous generations of models showed a diurnal cycle of convection (thunderstorms) but weren't able to simulate growth of the cirrus cloud canopy and the expanding cold rings aloft--features that are evident in nature. Progress under this proposal would build on previous work and improve our knowledge in this area of tropical meteorology.

Broader Impacts
This study will improve our understanding of the role of radiation in tropical cyclogenesis and could eventually lead to improved forecasting of these destructive storms. This research should help us understand how tropical cyclogenesis in future climates may differ from the present. Results will be disseminated to the community through conferences, workshops and published in peer-reviewed journals. A web site will be established to more broadly disseminate research results and provide open communications with the community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mechanisms leading to the formation of a hurricane are extremely complex. The first stage in the development of a hurricane is when a tropical disturbance strengthens into a tropical depression, which is known as tropical cyclogenesis. Sophisticated computer models are now able to explore tropical cyclogenesis in detail by explicitly resolving cloud processes, leading to significant advances in our understanding. One factor that has come to light from these studies is the importance of radiative processes, which involve the absorption and emission of solar and infrared radiation both by air and cloud hydrometeors. Computer model simulations can be run both with radiation included and without, and it has been found that inclusion of radiation typically accelerates the rate of tropical cyclogenesis by a factor of two. This study investigated the physical mechanisms causing radiation to accelerate tropical cyclogenesis in these computer simulations.

     Results showed that in the cloud-free air surrounding the tropical disturbance outgoing infrared radiation tended to cool the air, however in the tropical disturbance the canopy of cloud that had developed aloft tended to prevent infrared radiation from escaping to space. All things being equal this trapping of infrared radiation would cause the air under the canopy to become warmer relative to the surrounding cloud-free air than it otherwise would be. However, during the daytime the absorption of downward solar radiation tends to warm the surrounding cloud-free air, thereby counteracting the cooling that would otherwise occur. It is during the nighttime when solar heating is absent that the surrounding air cools significantly compared to the air underneath the cloud canopy of the tropical disturbance. Now cool air is negatively buoyant and tends to sink, while warm air is positively buoyant and tends to rise, so the effect of radiation at night is to induce a circulation that has upward motion in the tropical disturbance and downward motion in its surrounding environment. While this induced ascent is very weak, only several millimeters per second, over the course of the night it can cause upward displacement of air by as much as two hundred meters or more. This study has shown that it is this upward displacement of air in a deep layer underneath the cloud canopy which is responsible for accelerating the rate of tropical cyclogenesis.

    Computer model experiments were performed to understand precisely how the induced ascent caused by radiation during the night led to an increased rate of tropical cyclogenesis. It was found that the ascent increases the relative humidity through a deep layer and also makes the atmosphere increasingly unstable to convective motions. Both factors lead to stronger convective storms within the tropical disturbance and this promotes faster development into a tropical cyclone. Furthermore this process which operates during the nighttime, explains why there is a diurnal cycle of convective activity and upper-level cirrus cloud extent.

     In addition to the idealized simulations a case study of Hurricane Matthew (2016) was conducted to investigate these effects of radiation in more realistic conditions. Simulations also showed that radiation accelerates tropical cyclogenesis when the environment is vertically sheared and sometimes promotes convective bursts during the early stages of tropical cyclone development.

    This study has contributed to unraveling the important role of radiative processes in the early stages of hurricane formation. This increased understanding of the importance of radiation emphasizes the need for improved representation of radiative processes in operational hurricane forecast models. This is likely to provide more reliable prediction of hurricane formation and therefore allow more time for communities to prepare in advance of these dangerous weather systems.
